subject: RE: [junit] parallel test directories and eclipse
msgSnippet: Hello Bill, I ve been using such a project structure successfully since I first tried Eclipse.  I mark both src/java and src/test as source folders via the
messageBody:
Hello Bill,

I've been using such a project structure successfully since I first tried
Eclipse. I mark both src/java and src/test as source folders via the
project properties dialog. Alternately, you can right click on the project
and create new source folders whose root is src/java and src/test. Then
right click on the src/java folder and create a package named a.b.c and
Eclipse will create the folder structure for you under src/java; repeat for
src/test. Note, all of this applies to the Package Explorer view of the
Java perspective.

Good luck,
Craig

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Bill de hÓra [mailto:dehora@...]
> Sent: Wednesday, November 13, 2002 12:59 PM
> To: junit
> Subject: [junit] parallel test directories and eclipse
>
>
> Hi,
>
> Has anyone had any success getting Eclipse to understand a project
> whose junit code is organized as follows:
>
> src/
> java/
> a/b/c
> test/
> a/b/c
>
> I imagine it can be done, but I've not been able to get Eclipse to
> shut up - it says it can't find src/test's dependencies, ie the ones
> in src/java
>
> Bill de hÓra
>
>
